thread.title: London Mayor Sadiq Khan issues Brexit warning to North East on Tyneside visit

author: Chris Knight
title: London Mayor Sadiq Khan issues Brexit warning to North East on Tyneside visit
text:

London Mayor Sadiq Khan has warned the North East will suffer job losses and a reduced quality of life in the event of a hard Brexit. 
Recent analysis carried out by the Government projected the region’s economy will shrink by 11% if a comprehensive trade deal is agreed. 
This is forecast to rise to 16% of the North East’s GDP if no Brexit deal is agreed. 
And speaking on a visit to Tyneside on Saturday, Mr Khan issued a stark warning about the region’s future beyond the European Union. 
He said: “I’m really worried about the consequences of us leaving on a harder Brexit. We have commissioned independent economists to do an assessment of the consequences of us leaving the EU based on a number of different scenarios. 
“The bad news for the North East is I’m afraid you will see less jobs created, you will see some of your sectors diminishing and a huge impact on the quality of life. (Image: Getty Images Europe) 
“It’s important the Government negotiates and realise there are a number of options on the table. What they have to negotiate for is one that is least damaging to the country’s economy and the North East economy, meaning a soft Brexit. 
“In my view, we should stay in the single market and the customs market even though we’re outside the European Union. My worry is the Prime Minister is thinking about political party interests rather than national interests.” 
Mr Khan spent time in Newcastle’s West End with local Labour party members on Saturday afternoon, before speaking at the Discovery Museum’s Grand Hall at an event celebrating the 15th anniversary of immigration law firm Latif Solicitors. He said: “We should celebrate the contributions of immigrants over successive generations but also lawyers who play a crucial role in taking on cases and then winning them to give people who came from other countries the right to remain in the UK. 
“Because these cases take so long to process, immigrants start a family here and it’s really harsh and unfair for them to be sent back ‘home’ because this has become their home. 
“If a person is from a country they have not seen since they were a baby, how can you honestly send that person ‘home’? 
“What the Government should be doing is making sure cases are dealt with quicker, but also realise one of the reasons we’re respected around the world is because of good immigration. 
“It is important we support good immigration, economically, socially and culturally, for their massive contribution to our country and long may that continue.” 
Liaquat Latif, owner of the firm, also spoke at the event surrounding the importance of Article 8 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. 
Mr Latif has known the London Mayor since their days at the University of North London in 1989, and says Mr Khan did not take much convincing to speak on human rights in the North East. 
Mr Latif, 47, said: “The general theme of our event today is the protection of human rights in the current climate. 
He added: “Mr Khan really likes Newcastle. He has a real affinity with the area, and there’s so many places we have visited together. 
“He loves getting his fish and chips from the coast!” Like us on Facebook
